data.title: Cabinet reshuffle eases Greek crisis
data.meta_description: Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou replaced his finance minister Friday in a Cabinet reshuffle that raised hopes that austerity measures will now be passed to prevent a debt default.
data.text:
— Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou replaced his finance minister Friday in a Cabinet reshuffle that raised hopes that austerity measures will now be passed to prevent a debt default.

After two days of political chaos that threatened to topple the Greek government, Germany also appeared ready to provide billions more in aid to carry the debt ridden country through 2014. German Chancellor Angela Merkel indicated that the private sector would not be forced to assist in a second bailout.

Yields on Greek 10-year bonds dropped more than a percentage point to the still sky-high level of just less than 17 percent, while the Athens Stock Market closed up 3.8 percent at 1,254.02. U.S. stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 42.84 points to 12,004.36.

Papandreou fired Finance Minister George Papaconstantinou, the target of ire

among the ruling Socialists

for deepening budget-deficit

cuts, in an overhaul aimed at

fending off a party rebellion

and ensuring the passage of

austerity measures needed for

a bailout. Papaconstantinou retains a ministerial position.

“The country must be

saved, and it will be saved,”

said Evangelos Venizelos,

who moved from the Defense

Ministry to take the reins at

the Finance Ministry. “I am

leaving defense today to go

to the real war.” By promoting Venizelos,

who challenged Papandreou

for the party leadership four

years ago, to the Finance Ministry, Papandreou will hope he

met demands of his deputies

so that the new package will

get passed. At a seven-hour

meeting Thursday, Socialist

lawmakers demanded he re

move inexperienced loyalists

from the Cabinet and replace

them with more experienced

party veterans.

“We are facing the greatest

threat our country has experienced in recent decades,”

the prime minister said at

the first meeting of his new

Cabinet.

“We are again at a critical juncture in the middle of

a difficult negotiation that is

crucial for the future of the

country - for an immediate

solution of a major national

problem, the problem of debt

that threatens to destroy us

and destroy the lives of mil

lions of Greeks,” he said.

Papandreou has struggled

to build support for a new

package of about $40 bil

lion in spending cuts and tax

increases demanded by the

European Union and International Monetary Fund, which

granted Greece’s first bailout

loans last year in return for

austerity measures. The pack

age must be voted through

Parliament this month if the

country is to continue receiving funds from its bailout.

Venizelos, who is expected

to attend a meeting of euro

zone finance ministers in

Luxembourg on Sunday and

Monday, renewed a call to the

opposition Conservatives to

join the effort of overhauling

Greece’s economy.

Papandreou will travel to

Brussels on Monday to meet

with European Commission

President Jose Manuel Barroso to assuage fears about

Greece’s commitment to the

bailout program. For weeks,

the commission has called

for cross-party support for

the new tax increases and

pay cuts, since the measures

would continue beyond the

end of Papandreou’s term.

The prime minister had

tried earlier this week to negotiate with Conservatives

to form a coalition government, but the talks collapsed

Wednesday in Athens, and

protesters battled police in the

streets outside Parliament.

The reshuffle is partly

a response to the failure of

those talks. The appointment

of Venizelos, the 57-year-old

constitutional law professor,

is designed to give Papandreou the necessary votes in

Parliament, where his Socialists have a majority by five

seats.

Venizelos is considered

Papandreou’s main internal

Socialist rival. A veteran of

several ministries, he handled

the run-up to Greece’s hosting of the Olympic Games in

2004 as culture minister.

Government portfolios

were also redistributed to

address demands for faster

change from Greece’s debt

monitors at the European

Union and IMF. A new Minis

try for Administrative Reform

was created to help scale back

the country’s public sector.

Venizelos’ immediate

task is to get on top of bud

get slippages and setbacks

in cost-cutting changes as

well as pushing ahead with

a privatization drive worth

$70.5 billion. At the same

time, he will have to negoti

ate a second bailout package

with Greece’s frustrated in

ternational creditors.

All this, though, hinges on

whether Papandreou’s new

government wins a confi

dence vote in Parliament,

likely at midnight Tuesday.

Socialist dissenters have

given no indication they

will vote against the govern

ment, but one rebel said he

would not back new auster

ity measures without “major

changes.” If the government clears

that hurdle, there appears

to be a greater chance that

Greece will get a second

bailout. On Friday, Germany’s

Merkel agreed with FrenchPresident Nicolas Sarkozy that private investors should be part of the solution but that their participation had to be “voluntary.” “We would like to have a participation of private creditors on a voluntary basis,” Merkel said in Berlin at a joint news conference with Sarkozy. This “should be worked out jointly with the [European Central Bank] and there shouldn’t be any dispute with the ECB on this.” Merkel declined to give a date for the detail of the aid package to be worked out, saying the matter must be resolved quickly.

JPMorgan Chase & Co.

analysts wrote in a research note that “Germany appears to have backed down” and welcomed the move as the clearing of a key obstacle toa solution for Greece.

“As of last night, there were two main obstacles to sealing a package for Greece: disagreement among European policymakers, and Greek politics,” said Nicola Mai, an analyst at JPMorgan. “Following a meeting between Merkel and Sarkozy this morning, the first of these two obstacles appears to have been lifted.” The government has also promised to cut its public service by 150,000 people by 2015 and effectively end lifetime government jobs. The privatization program will also have to kick up a gear or two, particularly in the energy sector.

Dealing with the debt burden is going to take years, analysts say. Many in the markets still think it’s an impossible job and that a default is inevitable.

Information for this article was contributed by Elena Becatoros, Derek Gatopoulos, Gabriele Steinhauser and Melissa Eddy of The Associated Press and by Maria Petrakis, Natalie Weeks, Tony Czuczka and Helene Fouquet of Bloomberg News.
